The exaggerated time frame of 2 minutes conveys sarcasm, implying that the person's reaction is not actually understandable given the short amount of time they waited for a reply.

In contrast, option (A) - "His reaction is understandable—he didn't get a reply in 2 years" - is not sarcastic. Waiting 2 years for a reply is a much more reasonable timeframe to be frustrated by the lack of response, so this statement does not contain the same ironic or satirical undertones.

Therefore, the sarcastic statement is option (B).

Statement (A) says "Hmm, stifling of free speech and political opinions . . . I've seen that before". This statement is sarcastic because it implies that the stifling of free speech and political opinions is a common occurrence, which goes against the ideal of free and open discourse.

The sarcasm comes from the juxtaposition of "stifling of free speech and political opinions" with "I've seen that before", suggesting that this is a regular or expected phenomenon, when in reality it should be seen as undesirable and something that should not be readily accepted.

In contrast, statement (B) "Hmm, stifling of free speech and political opinions . . . never seen that before" is more straightforward and does not contain the same sarcastic undertone. It simply expresses surprise or disbelief at the idea of free speech and political opinions being stifled, which is a more sincere response.

Therefore, the sarcastic statement is option (A).

The sarcastic statement is option (A): "Yeah, history is rarely black and white".

This statement is sarcastic because it implies the opposite of what it says. Describing history as "rarely black and white" suggests that history is actually quite complex and nuanced, rather than being simple and straightforward. 

However, the sarcastic tone implies that the speaker believes the common view is that history is indeed "black and white" - overly simplistic and lacking nuance. By saying the opposite of what is typically believed, the speaker is using sarcasm to criticize this simplistic view of history.

In contrast, option (B) - "Yeah, history is usually black and white" - is a more straightforward, non-sarcastic statement, even though it may be debatable whether history is truly "black and white".

Therefore, the sarcastic statement is option (A).

The sarcastic statement is (A).

In contrast, statement (B) about being a "serious hockey fan" and wanting a "dead silent" and seated crowd is not sarcastic. It is simply an absurd and unrealistic expectation, as hockey games are known for their lively, energetic crowds.

Explanation:

Option (A) states "Showing up for work everyday helps makes you a great lawmaker". This statement is sarcastic because it implies that simply showing up to work every day is enough to make someone a great lawmaker, which is clearly not the case. The sarcasm lies in the fact that the statement contradicts the common understanding that being an effective lawmaker requires much more than just regular attendance.

In contrast, option (B) stating "Showing up for work everyday alone makes you a great lawmaker" is not sarcastic. It is simply an incorrect or hyperbolic statement, but does not contain the ironic or mocking tone that characterizes sarcasm.

So based on the definition of sarcasm provided, option (A) is the sarcastic statement out of the two choices.
